case_vignette: A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician because of bleeding from the nipple of her right breast for 3 months. There is no bleeding from the other breast. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and lasts for 5 days with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 53 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Breast examination shows bleeding of the right breast on application of pressure with no palpable mass. The left breast shows no abnormalities. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Ultrasonography shows a dilated duct enclosing a well-defined solitary mass.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been experiencing bleeding from the nipple of my right breast for the past 3 months.

No, I haven't had any breast pain or skin changes.
Do you have any family history of breast cancer or other cancers?
Yes, my mother died of breast cancer when she was 53 years old.
Have you noticed any changes in the color or odor of the nipple discharge?
No, I have not noticed any changes in the color or odor of the discharge.

The case vignette provided does not mention any information on pregnancies, so I cannot answer that.
Understood. Have you had any previous breast biopsies or surgeries?

No, I'm not taking any medications or supplements.
Have you experienced any other symptoms like unexplained weight loss, fatigue, or breast skin changes?
No, I haven't experienced weight loss, fatigue, or skin changes on my breast.
Final Diagnosis: Spontaneous unilateral nipple discharge in a woman with a family history of breast cancer likely warrants evaluation for intraductal pathology such as papilloma or malignancy.
